name: White Rabbit's Foot Fern
description: Humata tyermanii, commonly known as White Rabbit's Foot Fern, is an epiphytic fern native to tropical regions of Southeast Asia, particularly the Philippines and Indonesia. It belongs to the Davalliaceae family and features trailing fronds (30-60 cm long) with medium-sized, dramatic, finely divided, dark green fronds with distinctive white, furry rhizomes that resemble rabbit's feet. The plant displays a trailing growth habit. Thrives in the humid, shaded understory of tropical forests where it receives consistent moisture and protection from direct sunlight. In its native habitat, it grows on tree branches in tropical forests. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds vibrant colors and visual interest to any environment. It's popular among fern enthusiasts for its unique furry rhizomes.
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged
Avoid direct sunlight - prefers bright indirect light
Brown edges indicate low humidity or underwatering
